URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4935#issuecomment-516533172
 
 
   My bad, the test expectation that was finally able to be executed was written wrong. Here's the fix:
   
   ```diff
   --- a/r/tests/testthat/test-arrow-csv.R
   +++ b/r/tests/testthat/test-arrow-csv.R
   @@ -131,7 +131,7 @@ test_that("read_csv_arrow parsing options: skip_empty_rows", {
      tab1 <- read_csv_arrow(tf, skip_empty_rows = FALSE)
    
      expect_equal(nrow(tab1), nrow(iris) + 2)
   -  expect_true(is.na(tail(iris, 1)[[1]]))
   +  expect_true(is.na(tail(tab1, 1)[[1]]))
    })
   ```

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
Followup to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-5747. If {{ignore_empty_lines}} is false and there are empty lines, it fails to parse (again, with {{Invalid: Empty CSV file}}).

Correct behavior should be to fill those empty lines with missing data for all columns.
fields.summary: [C++] CSV reader ignore_empty_lines option doesn't handle empty lines

comments.body:
> Correct behavior should be to fill those empty lines with missing data for all columns.

Uh, why would it? I know CSV is not an extremely well-specified format, but that sounds to me a bit far-fetched. It's also a bit problematic: how do you deal with empty lines at the beginning of a file? You don't know the number of columns yet.

[~wesmckinn]
Hm, I am not sure about this. What do other CSV readers do (e.g. {{pandas.read_csv}}, {{readr::read_csv}}, {{datatable::fread}}, etc.)?

Pandas does this:
{code:python}
>>> pd.read_csv(io.BytesIO(b"""ab,cd\n12,34\n\r\n56,78\n"""))                                                                                                         
   ab  cd
0  12  34
1  56  78
>>> pd.read_csv(io.BytesIO(b"""ab,cd\n12,34\n\r\n56,78\n"""), skip_blank_lines=False)                                                                                 
     ab    cd
0  12.0  34.0
1   NaN   NaN
2  56.0  78.0
{code}
I'd expect the empty lines to be skipped, if one wants nulls, it should be a line of the exact number of commas.

[~fsaintjacques] skipping empty lines is still the default behaviour, those nulls are only introduced when specifying the keyword. I don't think we have plans to change the default, so the question is then more: is it worth having this option? (pandas.read_csv has it for example)

It's an option many (most? all?) of the other common CSV readers have, so we should have it too. File readers, especially CSV, need to support lots of funky data shapes because real data is usually dirty and it's not feasible to tell people to rewrite their data (or even if you could say that, well, you have to read it in order to be able to rewrite it, right?)
I was agreeing with the (current) default instead of adding nulls. I think it's worth having as an option.
This patch does not change the default, only correctly implements the option.
